Accounting 743 studies how complex financial structures account for their activities. Primary emphasis is on the application of purchase accounting for mergers and acquisitions, the equity method for investments, and preparing and interpreting consolidated financial statements. Other topics covered include translations and re-measurements for nondomestic investments, and earnings per share calculations for complex financial structures. Tax considerations and acquisition strategies are of only peripheral interest in this class, and students who are concerned primarily with those topics are advised to seek a different elective. 

Students commented that this course is extremely difficult and requires a great deal of work but will allow you to learn “a definitive skill set you can take away from Wharton.” The concepts are challenging and tend to be very technical and detailed. Students discourage anyone from taking the course if they are not strongly committed. Furthermore, students say that a lot of the course focuses on the preparation of consolidated financial statements rather than the interpretation of financial information. 

Professor Verrecchia received many mixed reviews. Students agree that he is very knowledgeable and demands hard work. Some comment that he is extremely stimulating and cares a lot about his students. Others note that he is “simply disinterested in student development” and does not convey the subject matter in an effective manner. 

A common note regarding this class is that it may “require 5-10 hours of prep per week.” Grades are based on 5 quizzes that are not too difficult but have very high means, causing a tight grade distribution. The course material is potentially useful for investors, investment bankers, and those going into M&A work, and is meant mainly for MBA students.
